Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2010 09:51AM Twinmom77 wrote: I'm 11 months out from chemo and mine is definitely worse than it was during chemo.  I had given up any hope of it getting better but reading some of the other posts, maybe it will.  What I hate is when I try to explain what it's like to someone (usually someone older than my 33 years) and the reaction I get is "Pffft, I've been going through that for years, it's just a part of getting older."  I hate, hate, hate that!!!  This is different, and I am not "older"!   AGGHHHH!!
Posts.Title: Chemo brain after chemo buyo pickle

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 05:39AM Twinmom77 wrote: Thanks Sandeew18, now I can say I've heard of someone going there and liking it!  I'm glad you're pleased with your experience there.  I'm really glad I went the integrative route as well because it seemed I had a lot less se's than others were experiencing.  Not that chemo was a day at the beach, but I'm convinced supplements definitely helped.  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Cancer Centers of America?? catwood revkat

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 12:40PM Twinmom77 wrote: I've never heard of anyone going there but I considered it. My mom tried to get me to go to the one in PA because they had some complementary/alternative treatment in addition to conventional treatment.  I talked on the phone with someone there and it was like she was trying to sell me on the place.  She supposedly had bc and some other cancer (or recurrence, I don't remember) and two young boys (like me) and her husband left her (like mine did) and nothing worked until she went to CTCA, etc, etc.  I wasn't feeling real great about the conversation but was giving her my info anyway and just then my cell phone died.  I took that as a sign and didn't call her back! I'm sure they're legitimate and if you're close to one it might be nice to be able to get all your treatment in one place.  I just wasn't comfortable with it and decided a local naturopath could help me with the alternative stuff while my local Onc took care of the conventional stuff.  And it ended up that my naturopath followed a lot of the protocol that the docs at CTCA follow so I'm glad I didn't spend the extra money to travel there just for that. Hope that helps a little and good luck to you!
Posts.Title: Cancer Centers of America?? catwood revkat

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 12:41PM - edited May 25, 2010 12:42PM by Twinmom77 Sorry, double post.
Posts.Title: Cancer Centers of America?? catwood revkat

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2010 05:59AM Twinmom77 wrote: Hi ladies!  I was terrified too, so much so that I kept putting off the appointments and trying to find excuses not to go.  I nearly refused rads I was so scared.  I was convinced the little strip of lung that would get rads too would ruin that lung for life, convinced I was going to have horrible skin damage. For one, ask as many questions you need to until you feel comfortable and understand what they are talking about.  I asked questions in the beginning but the techs kind of blew me off.  I didn't get brave enough to ask again (different tech) until the end and she explained things much better and I realized only a teeny tiny sliver of my lung was in the beam, not the whole lung.  I spent all that time worrying for nothing. Some people are laying on their backs, some on their bellies, some get 3 weeks, some get 7 weeks, some have their armpit and/or clavicle, some just the breast.  It all depends on your stats. How long you lay there varies too but it's usually only about 5 minutes from start to finish.  It usually takes longer for them to get you layed down and moved to the position they want you in and set up the machine than the actual radiation takes.  I had about 6 zaps on an angle from the right side and then the machine would move over to the left and go about another 7 times.  Each time varied from a few seconds to about 15 seconds. Side effects vary too.  For me, I was just red and itchy.  They prescribed me radiaplex and that helped a lot.  It took about two weeks for the redness to go away once I was done and about the same time is when the fatigue set in and lasted a couple weeks.  That was it!  I'm four months out and have had no problems with skin or lungs.  I do feel fatigued a lot, but I'm also finishing up my Herceptin so it's hard to say what the fatigue is from. I'm a person that believes the mind has a huge effect on our bodies.  I believe if you truly keep thinking something horrible is going to happen, there's a good possibility that it will and vice versa.  Someone told me to go in thinking about the rays of radiation as a silver bullet that's going to kill any leftover cancer.  I'm not a big Jesus person, but for some reason I decided to see it as rays of light coming from Jesus' hands healing me.  Or I'd pretend I was sunbathing nude on the beach cause the techs always had good music on!   Another great thing to use is Belleruth Naparstek's Meditation for Radiation Treatment.  I would listen to that every night while going to sleep and it helped a lot too. Good luck ladies - it seems like a lot in the beginning but you'll get through it quicker than you think.  I'm sure others will chime in with points I missed.
Posts.Title: what is radiation like alison34 Susantc

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 03:25PM Twinmom77 wrote: I had a re-resection too.  Piece of cake, no big deal.  I wasn't nervous like the first time because I knew exactly what was going to happen. I was less groggy waking up the second time because I wasn't under as long and they didn't use as much anesthesia.  I was in pain more the second time, which surprised me because I had no pain the first time, but it was nothing a little morphine in the recovery room couldn't fix :)  Recovery didn't take any longer than normal, I was up and around and ready to get a shower within 2-3 days.  I think more than anything, it's just a little disappointing, thinking you're all done and then having to go back.  You'll do great!
Posts.Title: How many others had to have more surgery? BioAdoptMom3 cantgarden

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2012 07:13AM Twinmom77 wrote: I am so glad to see that there's so many of you able to help eachother out with the chemo aspect. Although I did the TCH and Herceptin, I really don't remember a lot of the details so I am fairly useless.  So see ladies, this does all eventually fade to a distant memory! munny - some advice about the Tamoxifen...Don't read the threads on here about it!!!  I'm serious, just don't, don't, don't do it! Lol  I refused Tam the first time because I had some miserable side effects within the first 6 days and then quit it after 9 days. I had read all the threads about it and I was so scared of the side effects and so certain that I would get them. I think I actually ended up manifesting those side effects.  This time around, the Tam is my only option for tx so I every time I take a pill, I tell myself how good it is for me and how much I love taking it and how it's going to save my life.  It's corny, but hey, I'm 6 wks in and have had no problems.  And I stear clear of the Tam threads! As for me, I'm headed back to surgery tomorrow.  I developed an infection in the left side just yesterday and my PS wants to have a look around and see if he can save my TE's. I'm so discouraged and so sick of feeling sick. My dad and step mom had to come over and clean for me today and now they're going to be stuck taking care of my boys for the good part of the week...I'm just so tired of being a burdon to people and not being able to do things on my own. Or get out and enjoy this beautiful weather.  Sorry to be such a downer.  I'm usually very optimistic but I've deemed today "Wallow in self pity day". Tomorrow I will pick myself up and dust myself off and carry on.
Posts.Title: Ohio Chemo Sisters Kelloggs Kelloggs

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 03:12AM Twinmom77 wrote: Kellogg - congrats on your last TCH next week! That's gotta feel good...one more phase out of the way! munnybunni - sorry, I don't know anything about diabetes and a/c so I'm no help, but how was the appt? I'm off to the BS because I'm apparently having a reaction to the abx I've been on for 3 weeks (due to cellulitis, don't know if I mentioned that here). Can barely move my head and I walk like a zombie from crazy lower back pain. I'm certain it's the Bactrim...my sister had this same reaction a few years ago. I just want a week with no complications!!! Lol. Enjoy the weather all!
Posts.Title: Ohio Chemo Sisters Kelloggs Kelloggs

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 12:27PM Twinmom77 wrote: Hello Ohio ladies! Just found this thread and I hope you don't mind me joining in late...I'm in Akron. I was actually a 2 1/2 year survivor and then I got a new occurence in the other breast in December.  That damn pesky cancer!!  So I just had a BMX 6 wks ago and I'm in the middle of recon with the lovely TE's.  Had a bout with cellulitis (not sure it's over actually), and I still have one drain in...grrrrr.  No chemo or rads for me this time around, just Tamoxifen. I didn't get a chance to read all the posts so I'm not sure where everyone is at in their tx, but for those in the middle of everything - the road seems impossibly long but you'll get there. It goes faster than you think, although not fast enough when you're in the midst of it, lol. Especially a year of Herceptin. I remember being so darn sick of that drug by about the 13th tx, but it must have worked because I was HER2- this time. Life does return to normal and you eventually start to feel wonderful again.  Funny that a couple of you are coders...I was in the coding program at Stark State but had to quit for now.  I'm hoping I can find a med office job soon here and continue the program next Jan.  Anyway, nice to meet you all!
Posts.Title: Ohio Chemo Sisters Kelloggs Kelloggs

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2010 07:20PM Twinmom77 wrote: frangi - yes, having my hands full was a daily thing before cancer!  My boys dealt with it really well which really suprised me.  I told them that mommy had an ouchie inside and that she would go to the doctor to get medicine to make it go away and that the medicine would make mommy's hair fall out.  I told them sometimes I would have to rest a lot and that grandma, grandpa, or auntie would take them for a camp-out (what we call a sleepover! ) at their house.  They love going to family's house anyway so this worked out really well.  (Their dad is a truck driver and was gone a lot so he wasn't around much to help...actually didn't WANT to help.  We have since separated.)  Every time I'd get back from any doc visits they would ask if my ouchie was gone yet - it was so cute, but kinda sad at the same time.  I'd tell them it wasn't gone yet but that the medicine was working really well and I would be fine.  We use the word 'safe' a lot, so I always made sure to tell them that whomever they were staying with would keep them safe while mommy was resting or in the hospital or getting medicine. At this point we have some lingering potty training issues, but they've been through 4 moves in 4 years and adjusting to their dad leaving so I couldn't really say that the issues stem from just mommy being sick...it's probably a little bit of everything! As for helping out, I'd be glad to...just didn't feel like I'd have much to contribute.  But let me know when, how often, and if there's a certain thing I should post or just whatever's going on with me and I'll be glad to help!
Posts.Title: Any Mums with Teens/Young Kids? frangipangi juliaw

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 05:51AM Twinmom77 wrote: A biopsy is the only way to tell 100%.  My breast surgeon told me it was cancer before the biopsy and I'm glad she did.  She said she wished she could tell me it was anything but cancer, but that I needed to prepare myself because from what she was seeing it was.  Now I didn't have to wait two weeks for a biopsy - mine was the next morning - but yes, I think docs that see this type of thing all the time can usually tell just by feeling and looking at the mammogram if you're dealing with something cancerous.  I would suggest she try to get the appointment moved up as well, only for her peace of mind, not because I think there's anything wrong.  Before the biopsy, they wanted me to wait three weeks to get an ultrasound and mammogram.  I called back and told them I'd go crazy if I had to wait and worry for three weeks and they moved it to the next day at a different hospital.  Hoping that her doc is wrong and she gets B9 results!

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2010 01:40PM Twinmom77 wrote: I think this is so great!  My twins were 3 when I was diagnosed and for awhile I really felt like the only young mom with young kids.  Now I know that there's lots more out there like us, unfortunately.  Your website is awesome.  I'm just finishing up treatment and I don't feel like I'd have much to offer at this point, but perhaps when I'm more 'seasoned' I'll feel more confident about helping other moms with little ones.

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2012 10:00AM Twinmom77 wrote: I felt the exact same way as you after finishing chemo, rads, and herceptin. I just wanted to be done with it all so, yes, I chose not to take it for the first dx after having some bad side effects.  But I got a 2nd primary 2 1/2 years later so I'm choosing to take it now. Plus onc said it was non-negotiable this time. I have had very few side effects this time around. I don't relish the thought of being on this drug for the next 5 years but I don't relish the thought of getting a 3rd primary or skipping straight to Stage IV either.  I steer clear of most Tamoxifen threads here except the one that was started recently about women who are NOT having bad se's. Maxine - how are you doing with the ovarian supp inj? How are the se's with that? I've asked my onc about doing that after Tamoxifen instead of ooph, but she doesn't seem to think it would be as beneficial for me as an ooph. I'll be 40 by the time I'm done with Tam and I really don't want an ooph.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 06:28AM Twinmom77 wrote: Wow! That's a lot of info and it can be scary when you don't know what half of it means.  I'm no expert and I don't know what a lot of those things mean, but I don't see anything that sounds absolutely horrible at this point.  I think the most important statements are: "No areas of architechtual distortion or suspicious microcalcification" - that's a good thing! "most likely represents cycts" - another good thing "recommend ultrasound to rule out solid abnormality" - they're just being cautious and checking it out...another good thing! I know you're scared and it's near impossible to put it out of your mind, but take a deep breath (or 10) and try to keep busy today to keep your mind off of it. Hugs to you! Let us know how it goes tomorrow.

Posts.Title: Chemo and period not stopping JSB Scoobydoo

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2010 04:40PM Twinmom77 wrote: I was on the same regimen you are but I stopped after 5 txs.  There was a difference in the lump after each tx, but more noticeably after #1 and #4.  I would usually notice the difference about a week after tx.  It didn't shrink exactly, but kind of got flatter and felt more like it was disintegrating (sp?) rather than shrinking. They never did any MRIs/mammos/ultrasounds to measure it during the course of tx - they always just felt for it. My BS was able to do a lumpectomy and there was no trace of IDC but there was some DCIS still.  Overall, I had a good experience with this regimen...well, as good as you can get for having to go through chemo! Good luck and hugs to you!
Posts.Title: Diagnosed in January bcfighter Twinmom77

Posts.Content: Twinmom77 wrote: I was just diagnosed last Friday.  Stage 1, grade 3 tumor.  Waiting on the BRAC results.  I don't know any other details.  I honestly thought maybe they'd just do a lumpectomy and radiation.  They say I have to have chemo.  I was not ready to hear that and I'm not ready to her mastectomy if it comes to that.  I'm not ready to lose my hair.  I just want this thing out of me, I want to go back to a month ago when life was good and busy and I didn't know about this.  Will I ever stop feeling this way? 1st dx 6/09 IDC, Stage I, HER2/ER/PR+, 0/2 nodes Dx 6/12/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 7/21/2009 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Chemotherapy 7/21/2009 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 12/8/2009 Lumpectomy: Left; Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel Radiation Therapy 1/30/2010 Dx 12/23/2011, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 1/30/2012 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left, Right Surgery 1/30/2012 Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Hormonal Therapy 2/9/2012 Surgery Reconstruction (left); Reconstruction (right) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Terrified, angry, depressed Twinmom77 cancersister

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2010 12:32AM Twinmom77 wrote: I know how heartbreaking it is to think about your kids in all this.  They shouldn't have to go through this too.  That being said, they are resilient little buggers!  I think it all depends on how perceptive your kids are. My twins were 3 when I was diagnosed.  Since I was a stay-at-home-mom, I knew they would notice a lot of different things going on.  Mine are the type that pick up on subtle changes and act out if they're not kept in the loop, lol!  I kept it simple but I did tell them pretty much everything in a way they could understand.  Kids get really crazy ideas sometimes if you don't let them know what's going on...like "Maybe mommy's hair is gone because I was bad" or "Did I do something to make mommy sick?".  It seems absurd to us, but at that age they are still thinking the world revolves around them so it makes sense to them. I just told my kids that mommy had an ouchie and that I was going to be going to the doctor A LOT!  The doctor would give me medicine to make the ouchie go away, but that medicine would make me tired and make my hair fall out.  I held all my hair back and made a funny face at them to make them laugh.  I let them know that lots of family - grandmas, grandpas, and aunts - would be keeping them safe at their houses when mommy felt tired or sick.  They loved "camping out" at family's house so this worked out really well.  We tried to stick to a routine as much as possible and during my "good weeks" we'd try to do lots of fun stuff.  After I'd get home from chemo, they'd ask if my ouchie was gone, which was heartbreaking in one sense, but gave me the gumption to keep on keepin' on for them.  They had no issues with my hair.  They watched as mommy got a special "hair cut" and laughed at my bald head. It's a tough decision and it's going to vary from family to family and kid to kid.  Usually, the hospital has social workers available at no cost to patients so you might want to check in with one and discuss options for telling your little ones.  Ultimately though, you know your kids best and what will work best for your family so go with your gut.  Good luck to you, I know it's not easy with little ones.  Hugs!
Posts.Title: How to Tell Very Young Children.... mje123 dollymolly

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2010 01:05AM Twinmom77 wrote: While I don't have experience with bc AND abnormal paps at the same time, I have had abnormal paps in the past - for a few years actually.  I had a colposcopy and yes, that really hurts.  I've had a LEEP too and I felt absolutely nothing.  There was no pain or soreness afterward either and I've not had any abnormal paps since.  So if it were me, I'd wait to see what your onc thinks and then I'd go straight for the LEEP and skip another colposcopy.  Just my opinion!  Hugs to you!!
Posts.Title: possible cervical cancer gingersfavorite1 Twinmom77

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2010 11:13PM Twinmom77 wrote: I was thinking about the "stray cells" comment that somebody made...can't remember who originally posted that...anyway, I think it's important to realize that yes, there may be stray cells left after tx, but nearly everyone has cancer cells in their body.  Not just former cancer patients, EVERYONE.  Nearly all of us (as in all of us humans, not all of us cancer people) will have cancer cells in our bodies at one point or another in our lives, probably multiple times.  But some people's immune systems fight off the cells successfully, while others do not.   I guess my point is, so what if we have stray cells? So does everyone.  Does that really make us more likely to recur, especially when a lot of us have taken steps to change our lifestyle and bolster our immune systems?  What do you guys think?
Posts.Title: Remission or "cured"? Halah wobbly

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 09:33PM Twinmom77 wrote: Excruciating?  No.  Uncomfortable? Yes. I know it's probably different for every woman depending on the size, shape, density, etc of the breast, but honestly, once I had my first one I walked away thinking "What's all the fuss about?"  No, it's not exactly a pleasant experience, but I think it's more about the indignity of having a stranger squeeze and smoosh and flatten your boobs into all kinds of weird positions. For me, being small breasted, it was just a little uncomfortable having someone smoosh my boob down and clamp (bad choice of words, I know) it between two paddles, but it was by no means painful.  And I had extremely tender breasts at the time.  Chances are, they'll do an ultrasound first and may do a mammogram to get a clearer picture of the situation just to be safe.  You'll be just fine!
Posts.Title: What to expect with a mammogram? andrea72 Annabella58

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2010 12:38PM Twinmom77 wrote: Bumping this up and hope you get someone who might have a little more experience with this.  I'm interested in what your onc says too so update me when you can.
Posts.Title: possible cervical cancer gingersfavorite1 Twinmom77

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2010 09:16PM Twinmom77 wrote: I rarely did BSEs before my diagnosis.  I did them obsessively after diagnosis.  Then my surgeon told me that if I'm constantly feeling them, I'm not going to be able to tell the difference in breast changes due to my cycle or changes due to something else.  She said checking once a month after my period is enough.  So for once in my life, I actually listened!  If you're concerned about the area from the biopsy or any other area for that matter, take a good feel and then leave it alone for a month.  You're not going to notice any subtle changes if you're messing with it all the time.  And when you start worrying and those thoughts start creeping into your head yell "CANCEL, CANCEL, CANCEL!" (Or say it in your head so people don't think you're a lunatic.)  Being anxious and stressed all the time does not help your body out at all.
Posts.Title: Obsessed about feeling for lumps and doing SBEs brady0819 brady0819

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2010 11:07AM Twinmom77 wrote: So sorry you have to be here, but welcome! As far her being cold, she may just not know what to say or how to handle it.  Or perhaps she had someone close to her go through the same thing and your dx may remind her of that person/time.  One of my best friends never brought up my dx or tx or ever asked how I was doing, which hurt at first, but now I understand that she was so afraid of saying the wrong thing that she thought it was better not to talk about it at all. As far as getting time off of work:  there should be a social worker at your hospital that you can talk to about what your rights are.  I know I picked up a brochure once in my cancer center library that discussed cancer patient's rights in the workplace.  I would find out exactly what you're entitled to before you agree to use vacation time and before you talk to your boss.  Then you can present her with the facts.  Maybe get something from your doctors to that explains what you'll be going through and what time you may need off. If it seems like she is keeping this professional then maybe that's the best route for you to take with her - it doesn't sound like she's someone who knows how to offer emotional support. Hope that helps a little - big hugs to you!
Posts.Title: How can I ask my boss to be mre compassionate? NannaBaby CarynRose

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2010 02:11AM Twinmom77 wrote: I have no idea what the "official" word is on this.  I can bore you with my opinion :)  For me, as a stage I or II person, " in remission" means I had cancer once, I don't now, but I expect it to come back.  Since I choose to believe it won't come back, I don't use the term "in remission".  The mind is such a powerful thing and I truly think that what you put your whole heart into believing and feeling will come to fruition, no matter if what you believe is good or bad.  I've witnessed this too many times to believe otherwise. This is not to say that I don't have bad days where I have a weird headache and I'm convinced I have brain mets, but for the most part, I choose to believe that I am cancer-free and healthy and will remain so.
Posts.Title: Remission or "cured"? Halah wobbly

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 09:09AM Twinmom77 wrote: I know it's scary to even think about chemo.  My surgeon told me it looked like I may be stage 1 or even DCIS when she saw my mammogram.  I was thinking, "Great! Most likely I'll just have surgery and rads."  So I was devastated (and I mean laying on the floor hyperventiliating from crying so hard kind of devastated!) when I learned because of Grade 3 and being premenopausal/so young, I would have to have chemo, even with no spread.  So while I can't tell you for certain what they'll say, being Grade 3 may automatically get you chemo, especially if you end up being HER2+.  A lot of times they don't even give you an oncotype test with grade 3 because they already know you need chemo with an aggressive cancer. But everyone's situation is different even if you do have the same stats. Nobody wants to do chemo, but I will say that I didn't need to be so devastated.  It wasn't that bad.  Yes, it's inconvenient and it gets you down at times and you're tired a lot, but it goes very quickly and you're back to yourself before you know it. For now, try to take things one step at a time.  All you have to focus on at this moment is surgery.  It's hard not to think about all the what-ifs, but you'll just drive yourself crazy if you do.  Hang in there, hugs to you!
Posts.Title: Does what my surgeon said sound accurate? BioAdoptMom3 BioAdoptMom3

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2010 08:56AM Twinmom77 wrote: You've gotten great advice here.  Just wanted to reiterate and tell you to try and not self-diagnos.  I'm  Her2+, grade 3, but even with that, they told me the tumor had been growing anywhere from 2-4 years.  You'd be surprised at the number of women who had clear mammos not long before their diagnosis - women of all stages, grades, and types of cancer.  When you start reading up and comparing everything you read to your situation, you tend to get firm ideas in your head about what's going to happen.  Then if something changes and tx turns out to be different from what you expected, it can be a real blow.  So try to just remain open and flexible until you get some definitive answers.  I know it's easier said than done! Everyone's situation is different so there's no real exact answer to your questions.  But from my experience, I started chemo about 6 weeks after diagnosis, 9 wks after I found the lump.  I had enlarged lymph nodes and had them biopsied and they were normal.  As far as staging, I was told anything over 2 cm is automatically stage II, but that the tx plan doesn't really change whether you're I or II.  I was never staged because I had chemo first to shrink the mass, so I'll never know what the actual dimensions of my mass were.  My breast surgeon did the biopsy and once that came back she recommende chemo first, so I got several opinions with oncs, picked one and started chemo. You're in the hardest part of this right now.  The uncertainty and decision making is the hardest part.  Once you know what you're dealing with and tx starts things start to calm down.  Try to enjoy the rest of the weekend - hugs to you!
Posts.Title: Unfortunately New Suze35 lago

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2009 09:48PM Twinmom77 wrote: Well, I'm new to the club.  I start my first round of TCH on 7/21 and I'm pretty nervous.  I hate having to be here, but I'm glad I'm not alone!  I'm trying to prepare myself as much as possible, but reading about all the side effects really puts me in a bad mood! mnikityger - I was diagnosed on June 12th too and I'm in Ohio as well, in Akron.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2009 01:04PM Twinmom77 wrote: Hi shelclaire - I started TCH on the 21st and also have young kids - 3 year old twins.  I keep thinking that this would be a little easier if my kids were grown or in high school at least, but I'm sure each age has its issues when dealing with a mom who's got cancer! I was told that I might just see some hair thining also, but I'm not holding my breath.  My scalp has been very itchy ever since my first tx and it worries me.  My SE's have been pretty manageable too which I'm incredibly thankful for.  I'm handling this much better than I thought, aside from some intestinal issues.  My body seems to delight in taking me from one elimination extreme to the other if you know what I mean! You might want to check out the taxotere, carboplatin, herceptin thread - lots of good info and experience over there specific to what we're experiencing.  Take care!

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2009 01:06AM Twinmom77 wrote: I did it! One down, five to go!  I can tell all the other newbies who are scared to start that it's not so bad!  I don't have a port yet, so the worst part was my nurse having a little trouble sticking me, but otherwise it was a breeze.  I feel great right now, except that I didn't fill my Ativan rx and now I'm up at 1AM due to the steroids.  They didn't end up giving my benadryl because of the reaction I had six years ago, so I'm not sleepy.  I'm still a little nervous about how I'm going to feel in the next couple days, but I know I can handle it! Sorry, I have trouble remembering specific posts and names, but Thanks to all those further along in treatment for your support, congrats to everyone who made it through their first time, and good luck to everyone who's first is coming up.  We can do this! And hello to all the Ohio girls!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2009 05:32PM Twinmom77 wrote: Hi glassist - I got zapped with you on the 21st!  How are you feeling?

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2009 10:13PM Twinmom77 wrote: Hi shelclaire - I started TCH on the 21st.  It's nice (in a weird way!) to see another ER/PR+ HER2+ on here.  Makes me feel not as alone! I feel pretty good actually and I'm hoping it stays that way, other than I'm hungry but nothing sounds good to me.  I too have a Vitamin water addiction now!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2010 09:06AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:48AM by Twinmom77 I'm sorry you all are going through this.  I imagine you must feel pretty helpless and frustrated. I had a lumpectomy so I can't comment on a stay after surgery.  But I was in the hospital for three days for neutropenia and I hated every minute of it.  I couldn't get any of the things (besides meds, which they could have sent me home with) needed for true healing at the hospital.  I couldn't get good, restorative sleep because the nurses (god bless them) where in my room every 5 hours to give me a shot and take my vitals.  People's call buttons beeped, doors slammed, toilets flushed, people shouted, announcements were made over the loudspeaker...ALL. NIGHT. LONG.  The food was horrible.  It didn't taste horrible, it tasted really good.  But it was full of things nobody trying to heal from anything should be eating - white breads and pastas, no whole grains; canned fruits and vegetables, no fresh; things filled with added sugars and high fructose corn syrup; a "salad" with nutritionaly deficient iceberg lettuce, not nutrient-filled dark leafy greens.  And lastly, I was in quarantine which meant I couldn't see my family, friends, or my little guys who I missed like crazy.  Not good for morale. IMO, healing is much better done at home, not in all cases, but a lot of them!
Posts.Title: Aftercare,or any care TigerPuss CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 01:41PM Twinmom77 wrote: My appointment wasn't doom and gloom, but it wasn't exactly a party either.  It was just kinda cut and dry, this is what the plan is.  The nurse went over side effects, skin care, tips on eating and excercise, etc.  The doc came in and I asked her all my questions, she looked at my scars and told me the treatment plan.  Then I went to have the CT scans.  I was supposed to leave after that but they brought me back in for mapping and tattoos because I have a hard time finding babysitters and that way I wouldn't have to come back.  About a week and a half later I went in for the simulation and the next day I started tx.  I only see the doc once a week to check on my skin and it's really quick. My onc didn't want me on the Tam until after rads.  She said if there are side effects they want to be sure if it's the rads or the Tam.  But there's people doing both at the same time too, so I guess it depends on the doc. Don't know if that helps, but like I said, pretty boring stuff!
Posts.Title: What to Expect at Rads Office Pure carol1949

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2009 04:12PM Twinmom77 wrote: So is anyone else here doing TCH also?  How is it going?  And is anyone else juggling small children during all this?  Any tips on helping them deal with mommy not being able to play?  I have three year old twin boys and I'm so worried this is going to scar them for life!  Thanks!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 10:00AM Twinmom77 wrote: I haven't posted in a long time but I'm still hanging around too.  I just had #4 of 6 TCH yesterday and I won't be done until Nov 3rd - I might be left all alone here! niknak - I hear you about the allergies!  I never realized nose hair was so important and I now truly know what having your nose dripping - no, running - feels like! I pretty much have hair all over my body - it's just thin and slow growing.  I'm wondering whether to even out my hair or just let it go.  The hair that never fell out is about an inch long and there's quite a bit of it.  The hair that fell out is just tiny stubble right now, so I've got patches that are way longer in some places and I'm nearly bald in other places.  I love the "long" fuzz and hate to buzz it right now, but I might look a little better if I wasn't so patchy!  Gosh, just never thought I'd be thinking about these things!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee
